title: mbed sdk boot: fix IAR note
body: There's already PR (to master) that reintroduces cmain.S to fix IAR nonrtos bootup sequence. Thus we should update this comment to reflect that change

title: Update pull request template
body:
Here is the proposed update to the mbed-os pull request template. 
This is a strawman version to provoke discussion and agreement on a final updated version.

title: Revert partially "Remove Cortex A support from CMSIS/RTOS"
body:
This reverts commit 5f294451030ee1f7982afbb41c2badb7b986d822 - but only partially.

cmain.S for IAR is still required to keep mbed SDK boot process as it was. This
startup file for IAR is active for non-rtos projects.

Fixes #4330

Thanks to @YarivCol for reporting this. Tested locally with blinky mbed OS and mbed-dev gpio example (K64F board) - thus should be compatible with all new changes (new mbed boot that is coming to mbed OS).

title: Adjust Thread interface connect timeout
body:
## Description
Thread device needs to wait for connectivity:
* routers will create new network and get local connectivity
* end device will get connectivity once attached to existing network
* devices without network settings gets connectivity once commissioned and attached to network

This PR removes connection timeout from Thread interface connect method. Then end devices and devices without network configuration settings will try connection for ever. This change does not affect to routers as they will get local connectivity.


## Status
**READY**

## Migrations
If this PR changes any APIs or behaviors, give a short description of what *API users* should do when this PR is merged.

 NO


## Related PRs

## Todos
- [x] Tests
- [x] Documentation

## Steps to test or reproduce
* Set flag thread-use-static-link-config to false to get uncommissioned device
* Once device is started the ThreadInterface connect method does not return until device is commissioned and attached to the Thread network

title: Have objects depend on their respective compiler invocations
body:
# Description

Each of C, C++, ASM and linker now depend on their command line invocations.
For example, adding `-DFoo` to the mbed CLI invocation (`mbed compile -DFoo`)
would force a complete recompile. Further, switching build profiles will force
all C and C++ to recompile. The assembler flags are the same ¯\\\_(ツ)\_/¯.

Resolves #2412 

# TODO

- [x] manual verification that modifying each part of a build profile causes
  the appropriate rebuild
- [x] /morph test

title: Mbed compiler cannot find the EthernetInterface.h file from mbed-os (version 5.4.4.) with LPC4088 platform (even if the file is inside the mbed-os class)
body:
I cannot compile, from mbed compiler, a program using EthernetInterface.h from mbed-os (version 5.4.4.) because I get this error:
"Cannot open source input file "EthernetInterface.h": No such file or directory "#include "EthernetInterface.h""
I checked the EthernetInterface is well in the mbed-os library and I can also include another library from there but not EthernetInterface . I tried to use the external EthernetInterface designed for LPC boards but of course a ton of other conflicts pop up.
Also, if I switch the platform from LPC4088 to K64F, it works. So what is wrong with LPC4088?

title: STM32F4xx:  Using AnalogIn() for internal VBAT and TEMP measurements
Decode STDERR from compiler
body:
## Description
Strangely, python does not seem to treat streams as unicode by default. 
Therefore, we need to manually decode the STDERR stream from the compiler before
we use it as it might contain not-ascii characters.

Resolves #4318

cc @teetak01

## TODO
 - [ ] @teetak01 verifies that this has resolved his issue

title: STM32F3: Remove dependence upon a specific flash vector table location
body:
## Description
The STM32F3 cmsis_nvic code is currently checking for a specific flash address when determining if the vector table is in flash or RAM.  By changing the test to instead see if the vector table base is NOT set to
the RAM address, it simplifies the code, and removes the dependency on the flash vectors being located at a specific address.  This becomes important when adding a custom boot loader, which requires that the flash vector table location in the mbed project be at a different address.

## Status
READY

## Migrations
NO

## Related PRs
None

## Todos
None

## Deploy notes
None

## Steps to test or reproduce
Create an STM32F3 based project but with the flash vector table moved to a different location (requires modifying the VECT_TAB_OFFSET setting in your target's system_stm32f3xx.cpp file, and moving the KEEP(*(.isr_vector)) line from your target's ld file (e.g. STM32F303XC.ld) to a different location ; be sure to align it to a multiple of 0x200).  Without the changes from this commit, any attempt to set an interrupt handler will fail because the cmsis_nvic code will think the ISR vectors are already in RAM, since they are not at the expected flash address.  With the changes, setting interrupt handlers properly results in the copy of the flash ISR vectors into RAM before modification.

Update mbed TLS to version 2.5.0


## Status
READY


## Migrations
NO

## Deploy notes
The functions `mbedtls_aes_encrypt` and `mbedtls_aes_decrypt` have been deprecated from mbed TLS to introduce return codes for the hardware acceleration support. Because of these, you might get some deprecated warnings in some development platforms that already have hardware acceleration implemented.

title: "mbed compile -v' fails on Unicode error when printing out warning
body:
How to reproduce:

tested with mbed-cli 1.1.1

Example program.
```
#include "mbed.h"
#include <stdio.h>

main ()
{
    printf("Fail!\ŋ");
}
```

```
mbed import mbed-os
mbed compile -v
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc5 in position 35: ordinal not in range(128)
```

So the mbed-cli is in fact failing because it cannot print out the warning message correctly. That code compiles (with warning) fine with `mbed compile`

Of course that line is typoed bug, but the verbosity mode itself probably should not terminate compilation.

Moved from here: https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-cli/issues/488

title: Reduce test overhead in preperation for CMSIS 5
body: Reduce RAM consumption so all tests can still be built when using CMSIS/RTX5. Also reduce clutter by removing the per target stack size defines in the tests.

body: Temporarily remove the Cortex-A targets since these targets will not be supported by CMSIS5 initially.

title: Add support for ubirch boards
body:
Taken from the original PR:

## Description 
Add support for our ubirch boards. UBRIDGE is a board with a K82F, GSM modem and some other parts that is programmed via USB (using an adapter board based on a K20DX). USENSE is a small form factor low-power sensor module with a KL82z MCU and sub-1GHz RF.

The changes include a fix in the debug uart settings, allowing for boards without external oscillator. It also enables the TRNG in the K_82 MCU for mbed.

## Status
**IN DEVELOPMENT**


## Migrations
NO

## Todos
- [X] Tests

cc @thinkberg @0xc0170

I accidentally closed the old PR. Whoops.

title: Fix timeout units in events timing test
body:
A units mistake led to passing 20000 seconds instead of 20000 milliseconds to greentea. The would cause the test to spin for 6 hours if it got stuck anywhere.

Taken from commit 8b5dee8e46d22b426c81475396072ed543c644dc in the CMSIS_5 branch.

title: BEETLE: Remove unused and conflicting systick
body: Remove the systick_timer driver from the BEETLE. This driver is both unused and conflicts with the upcoming RTX5 PR.

title: Disable lwIP checksum-on-copy
body:
Current version of lwIP has a bug in its checksum-on-copy code - see

#4140 and https://savannah.nongnu.org/bugs/?50914

Pending a fix from lwIP, set LWIP_CHECKSUM_ON_COPY to 0 to work around.
Will impact performance.

@mikaleppanen , @geky - if there's not a patch for the bug in the next few days, I think we should do this.

title: Fix RAM vector table for NCS36510
body:
Fix the ram address of the vector table on the NCS36510. Also reserve space for it in the linker scripts.

This is based on  94a0256cad2485b23638bde3072641b45ce8b554 from the CMSIS_5 branch.

title: Limit ISR stack to 4k on NUCLEO_F429ZI
body:
Decrease the interrupt stack size of the NUCLEO_F429ZI to save space when building for IAR.

This is a cherry pick of 78d28ffaffe9e0eaa50b19ece36de5df49c824cf from the CMSIS_5 branch.

title: Fix NVIC_SetVector type in HAL for MAX32630FTHR
body:
Change the irq_handler parameter of NVIC_SetVector from a function
pointer to a uin32_t so it matches the cmsis specification. This
prevents the following problem from occurring in RTX5 when building
for IAR:
The error: Error[Pe167]: argument of type "void (*)(void)" is incompatible
with parameter of type "uint32_t".

Based on b5db96090c8066f9a4195b974ccb9ff07ec7b1f0 from the CMSIS_5 branch.

title: Remove ARM7 support and targets
body:
Remove ARM7 targets since they are no longer supported.

This is a cherry pick of aa5f1aed641e6f1515644adbea071ed7a50b0e23 from the CMSIS_5 branch.

title: Remove unsupported net libraries
body:
Remove all unsupported net libraries from features/unsupported. There's already lwip for mbed OS that we support, and cellular will come soon to the codebase reworked.

Plus remove unsupported/tests for these libraries.

Cherry-picked from 51bea19cd202689654320ad4ebbe7d28b04d0f01 on the CMSIS_5 branch.

title: Increase stm32 timeout for spi transfers
body:
## Description

Default timeout of 10ms was reported in #4300

There seems to be conditions or use cases where the system is loaded with
higher priority tasks so that SPI transfer would be delayed more than 10ms.

## Status
This PR is sent because of request for a quick fix and this should unblock the situation, nevertheless I am not sure that the problem is entirely understood.

## Steps to test or reproduce
How to reproduce the issue was not explained in the ticket.
The patch was not tested and needs to be tested by reporters of the issue #4300

title: STM32F4 SPI driver return error causing SD card driver to fail
body:
Note: This is just a template, so feel free to use/remove the unnecessary things

### Description
- Type: Bug

---------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug

**Target**
UBLOX_EVK_ODIN_W2 and NUCLEO_F429ZI

**Toolchain:**
GCC_ARM

**Toolchain version:**
4.9.3 20150529 (release)

**mbed-cli version:** 
1.0

**mbed-os sha:**
42be5c01a7f91292d5e27124ad9584236025f6ab

**DAPLink version:**
0221

**Expected behaviors**
SPI driver should be thread safe

**Actual behavior**
In a multithread environment. SPI driver returns TIMEOUT error from time to time, which the SD card driver is not handling, causing filesystem corruption.

I'm not sure if the spi driver is suppose to return -1 as error code because error code is not defined in the api. https://github.com/ARMmbed/sd-driver

Also I got a trace of the SPI signals using a logic analyser, all looks ok. Hence the error could only originate from the software.

The error originates from this line https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F4/device/stm32f4xx_hal_spi.c#L964 which is an HAL_TIMEOUT error.

I think when the thread running spi gets swapped out and back in again while receiving, the timeout check fails.

When I increase the timeout to 50ms from https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/stm_spi_api.c#L360, the problem seem to go away.

title: Update CMSIS-Core and RTX to version 5
body:
## Description
Main changes made by this PR:
- Update CMSIS to v5
- Update CMSIS-RTOS to v2
- Update RTX to v5
- Remove `NVIC_SetVector` and `NVIC_GetVector` from target code as it's provided by CMSIS
- Copy interrupt vector table ROM->RAM
- Rework boot sequence
- Add RTOS1 compatibility including CMSIS adapter and RTOS1 types for both C and C++ APIs
- Optimize memory usage in tests
- Redefine thread/main/isr stack sizes
- Remove Cortex A and ARM7 support

## Status
**IN DEVELOPMENT**

## Related PRs
List related PRs against other branches:
* PAL: https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-client-pal/pull/75
* MCR20 driver (mesh): https://github.com/ARMmbed/mcr20a-rf-driver/pull/9
* Docs: https://github.com/ARMmbed/Handbook/pull/160

## Todos
- [ ] Fix Oulu CI (PAL: https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-client-pal/pull/75)
- [x] Merge work in progress work from Martin 
- [x] Move docs to handbook repo (docs/cmsis_rtx.md)
- [x] Fix failing uVisor CI
- [x] Revert changes that make Nanostack examples pass (PI name) and fix it properly
- [x] Fix mesh minimal tests failing by merging https://github.com/ARMmbed/mcr20a-rf-driver/pull/9

title: Revome duplicate optimization flags in IAR export
body:
# Description

Compiling with some IAR exports would result in a warning/error message saying
```
[Su004]: Option -O can only occur once
```

This is a Bad Thing^TM.

Resolves  https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-cli/issues/487

## Why did this happen?

We had an incomplete filter for optimization options that would be put in the 
miscellaneous options section of the IAR project XML. It did not filter out 
some options, like `-Oh` and `-Ohz`

## Why this patch?

This patch fixes this bug by filtering out a wider range of optimization options
from the miscellaneous flags section.

# TODO
- [x] /morph export-build

title: Set mbed minor and patch version to 0 for master
body:
Currently the MBED_VERSION on master is set to 5.2.1 and 5.0.123 which is confusing. I can see two ways of fixit that:
- After we make a release we make a change on master to reflect the last released mbed version
- We set it to 0 to avoid cofusion and set it to release version for release branch. @adbridge favors this solution.

One possible issue with second approach is if someone will get an idea of disabling/enabling features basing on MBED_VERSION macro in their app, not that it would work now very well, so maybe it's not a problem after all.

title: Flash api nRF52840
body:
Notes:
Adding support for flashiap for nRF52840 devices. This is second pull request. This one was started from master branch (I did cherry pick of few commits). Tests were passed but... There is a nasty bug on master now: https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/issues/4237 . It is necessary to remove first line in hex files and run tests with switch --run:
1. compile:
mbed test -n "tests-mbed_drivers-flashiap" -t GCC_ARM -m NRF52840_dk -c
2. Remove first line in hex files
3. Rerun tests without compilation:
mbed test -n "tests-mbed_drivers-flashiap" -t GCC_ARM -m NRF52840_dk --run
4. Run these three steps for "tests-mbed_hal-flash" tests

## Status
READY

## Related Issues
https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/issues/4237

title: Documenting i2c_api.h
body:
Notes:
* Pull requests will not be accepted until the submitter has agreed to the [contributer agreement](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).

title: avoid 03/05 intel-hex records for nordic devices
body:
Use Intelhex::write_hex_file instead of IntelHex::tofile do the work.
Mentioned records types has no sense for nordic devices.
Sucha a record comes from *.hex file from the mbed-os sources build.

This PR solves https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/issues/4237

title: Release candidate for mbed-os-5.4.5
NSAPI - Don't send trailing garbage in DNS queries
body:
Observed during investigation of
https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/issues/4246 - DNS queries sent
the entire buffer, not just the bit filled in.

Inefficient, especially for 6LoWPAN, and a security hole - the trailing
data could be previously-used heap.

title: Refactor config system
body:
# Description

The config system was very difficult to read and understand, so I re-wrote a
good bit of it.

Major areas:
 - Method names are now more in line with what they do. No more "process_" crud
 - Does not modify target objects
 - Lazily computed.
 - Verification done through a json schema
 - No longer deletes keys from dictionaries
 - More testing

## Method naming

I changed the methods to use a verb other than "process" and made them more
terse. Here's a sample

old name                   | new name
---------------------------|-----------------------------------------
`process_config_parameters`| `add_unit_config` and `override_config`
`get_config_data`          | `config_data` (property)
`parameters_to_macros`     | `parameters_as_macros` (property)
`validate_config`          | `is_valid` (property, assert-able)
`add_cumulative_overrides` | `add` (on the CumulativeOverride object)

## Immutable targets

This change just makes things much easier to trace. Instead of the config
modifying the target, the toolchain just queries the config for the data that
it would have gotten from the target.

## Lazy config

Config is no longer eagerly computed. When you ask for a value that depends on
configuration data, it implicitly will compute the current configuration. This
configuration is cached, so subsequent calls will not re-compute. The advantage
of this is that if you add several files in a row, you don't re-compute config
after each file.

## Json schema

I stripped out all of the type verification code I could find and placed it into
a pair of json schemas. These schemas are then used in place of custom python.
The benefits of this strategy for verification is that it is significantly more
centralized and self-documenting.

## Remove dict deletes

Because they make the code _really_ hard to follow. To trace the code you have
to reason about if a key still exists or not. That's much more difficult when
compared to treating config data as immutable.

## Tests

I added some unit tests to verify that config is processed correctly. These
tests exercise the config an overrides features, and assert that config is
processed in the correct order. These are unit tests, and the integration tests
that we had before are still in place.

# Nitty gritty details

Mbed Configuration data is made up of units. A unit may be a target definition,
a library configuration file (`mbed_lib.json`) or the application configuration
(`mbed_app.json`). These files are processed in order from the base target to
the application config. At each step, configuration parameters are built from
several keys:
 1) `config`: naming and adding configuration parameters
 2) `target_overrides`, or for targets just `overrides`: overwriting prior
    values of configuration parameters
 3) `macros`: adding name to value mappings directly to the compiler
    pre-processor

Each of these units first add config, then override config, and finally add
macros.

The code of the Config object is now structured to mimic this process.

The entry point for computing config is the `config_data` property, which will
elide generating the config data if the data is in the cache is not stale. When
the cache is stale or config has not yet been computed, `config_data` builds a
list of all config units to process, and calls the `unit_config_then_overrides`
funciton on each unit in order.

The `unit_config_then_overrides` function calls each of the helper function for
each of the steps mentioned above in order, if the configuration unit updates
them.

I did not see any reason for it to be more complicated than that

# TODO
- [ ] Document the json schema requirements
- [ ] Probably a nightly run
- [ ] Other documentation as @sg- is likely to request

title: STM32 NUCLEO boards with Ethernet connector: solve conflict with D11 arduino pin
body:
## Description

STM32 NUCLEO boards with Ethernet connector are:
- NUCLEO_F207ZG
- NUCLEO_F429ZI
- NUCLEO_F746ZG
- NUCLEO_F767ZI

If you are using Ethernet, and not SPI Arduino pins:
=> keep your board with the default configuration

If you are using SPI Arduino pins, and not Ethernet:
=> you should remove the JP6 bridge on the front side of the board

If you need SPI Arduino and Ethernet:
=> you have to patch the NUCLEO board on the back side: set solder bridge SB121 to off, and SB122 to on
=> D11 is no more connected to PA_7 but to PB_5
=> enable ETHERNET_SPI_D11_CONFLICT macro in mbed_app.json file


## Status
READY

title: cmsis5: remove unsupported/net libraries
body:
This pull request removes unsupported/net libraries that are no longer supported and we have already replacements (cellular is open PR here).

This should remove features/unsupported/net + tests + tools. Any reference for these to be removed. It is sent to features_cmsis5 branch as we continue cleaning up dependencies on rtx4 (I can redirect this to master if needed).

Split into two commits - one removes sources, the second one tools updates (mbed 2 tools that are referencing these libs being removed).

This removal means these libs are only available on developer page (cellular, lwip).

cc @bulislaw @sg- @geky @kjbracey-arm @theotherjimmy - to be aware of this removal

body: Introducing this compatibility layer will make transition (And ordering of changes) to RTOS2 easier.

title: stm32f4xx: Consider all DMA ready/busy states in conditionals
body:
Fix for #4262 

This fixes potential corner case issues relating to
stopping, starting, init/deinit, and setting callbacks.

The issue is only found with the stm32f4xx targets.

title: STM32F4XX: DMA HAL busy/ready conditionals are incorrect
STM32F4XX HAL: stopping ADC DMA can incorrectly return error
body:
**Overview**
`HAL_ADC_Stop_DMA()` can incorrectly return `HAL_DMA_ERROR_NO_XFER` and may not properly stop the DMA engine.

**Target**
`stm32f4xx`. I found this on the [Nucleo_F446RE](https://developer.mbed.org/platforms/ST-Nucleo-F446RE/)

**other thoughts**
If there is an abort request while DMA is not busy, should it really be considered an ERROR? Maybe instead it should just return `HAL_OK`. Any thoughts?

title: Inherit Xadow M0 target from LPC11U35_501
body:
I will try again with the comma deleted as @theotherjimmy suggested in 
my previous attempt. If this fails CI, I truly give up :)

targets/targets.json already added MCU_LPC11U35_501 as an extra label
but it didn't have LPC11U35_501 (without the MCU_ prefix). Both of
these target names are used as folder names to organize files
specific to this device. For example the LPC11U35.ld linker script used
by GCC_ARM for this target is located in a TARGET_LPC11U35_501 folder.

I switched to using inheritance to properly setup the target labels
based on @theotherjimmy comments on PR #4252. Everything in the
XADOW_M0 target appears to have been copy/pasted from LPC11U35_501
anyway so inheritance seems to be the best way to set the values of
the XADOW_M0 properties.

title: Add error check in Stream constructor
body:
Proposal following discussion on #687 

## Description
On small targets there might be memory issues that lead to failing on file allocaiton / opening during Stream creation.

The consequence was application continues running, but any printf
to the Serial object whose Stream was not properly created
would not show any error (and characters would not show either)

Let's add a check to be properly inform user of the error.


## Status
**READY**

title: CMSIS5: Encapsulate usage of private RTX structures to one header file
body:
mbed OS requires access to internal RTX structures, to use them as RTOS
object's backing storage. To avoid contaminating multiple places across
mbed sources, all required types are typedefed in one header file.

@0xc0170

The STM32F103RB and STM32F10C8 are identical mcu and only differ in flash size, so the support of mbed os for one and not the other is not reasonable.

title: Fix C++11 build error w/ u-blox EVK-ODIN-W2
body:
When attempting to perform a test build of various mbed-os targets with
GCC configured to build -std=gnu++11, all of the targets built
successfully except for this one. It gave errors like this:
```
    ../mbed-os/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F4/TARGET_UBLOX_EVK_ODIN_W2/sdk/wifi_emac/wifi_emac_api.cpp: In function 'emac_interface_t* wifi_emac_get_interface()':
    ../mbed-os/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F4/TARGET_UBLOX_EVK_ODIN_W2/sdk/wifi_emac/wifi_emac_api.cpp:331:38: error: use of deleted function 'emac_interface::emac_interface()'
             _intf = new emac_interface_t();
                                          ^
    In file included from ../mbed-os/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F4/TARGET_UBLOX_EVK_ODIN_W2/sdk/wifi_emac/wifi_emac_api.cpp:9:0:
    ../mbed-os/hal/emac_api.h:150:16: note: 'emac_interface::emac_interface()' is implicitly deleted because the default definition would be ill-formed:
     typedef struct emac_interface {
                    ^
    ../mbed-os/hal/emac_api.h:150:16: error: uninitialized const member in 'struct emac_interface'
    ../mbed-os/hal/emac_api.h:151:32: note: 'const emac_interface_ops_t emac_interface::ops' should be initialized
         const emac_interface_ops_t ops;
```
This commit contains a proposed change which fixes this issue by not
using the new operator to allocate the emac_interface_t structure but
instead using the malloc() function since the construction is being
handled explicitly in the subsequent lines of the
wifi_emac_get_interface() function anyway.

I also added code which only completes the initialization of the _intf
object if its allocation succeeds and just returns NULL otherwise.

I see no deallocation of the _intf object occurring so no change from
delete to free() needed to be made.

title: USB Device support broken for K64F
body:
### Description
- Type: Bug | Enhancement | Question
- Priority: Minor (as USB is unsupported, though someone might want to investigate and fix)

---------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug

**Target**
K64F

**Toolchain:**
ARM

**Toolchain version:**
5.06

**mbed-cli version:** 
1.1.1

**meed-os sha:**
mbed-os-5.4.4 release

**DAPLink version:**

**Expected behavior**
Trying USBMouse HelloWorld example from the mbed Developer Site, where mbed library is replaced by mbed-os. For STM32 and Nuvoton boards the steps to reproduce below work just fine both with mbed Classic library (rev 140) and mbed-os (5.4.4).

**Actual behavior**
Example program compiles fine but getting USB Device not recognized on Windows 7. Having 2x K64F therefore is highly unlikely tobe HW bug.

**Steps to reproduce**
1. Import USBMouse_HelloWorld https://developer.mbed.org/users/samux/code/USBMouse_HelloWorld/ (code dates back to 2013!)
2. Remove USBDevice library
3. Add/clone my fork at https://developer.mbed.org/users/screamer/code/USBDevice/ and switch to branch stm32-support, which is identical to mbed-os/features/unsupported/USBDevice
4. Update mbed library or replace with mbed-os
5. Compile in the mbed Online IDE or `mbed compile -t ARM -m NUCLEO_F429ZI`
6. Flash the board and then change USB connection from STLink to USB Device port

title: Add consistent button names across targets
body:
## Description
There's currently no standardization across device switch names (as we do with LED names). This change maps currently existing switch mappings to a 1-indexed BUTTON name.

Related to https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/issues/4032

## Migrations
This change does not modify any existing applications, it only provides a new button name option.

## Testing
Built without error and tested functionality on a K64F

## Concerns
The DELTA_DFCM_NNN40 uses BUTTON0 as its mapped name already so I did not modify that file. 

I did not touch all targets, I started with targets that defined switches in some way in PinNames.h through an automated script and may have missed some. Pushing forward with the bulk of what I have.

cc
@mray19027 @bridadan

title: [NRF5 + NRF52840]: Merge nrf52840 to [NRF5] sources
body:
## Description
Former nRF52840 was based on its private api hal drivers and ble implementation. This PR merge those nRF52840 changes to NRF5.

nRF5 SDK base codes and softdevice versions are **not changed** for mcu targets.

changes:
renamed dir. NRF5/sdk -> NRF5/TARGET_SDK11
moved dir. NRF5_SDK13/sdk -> NR5/TARGET_SDK13
moved dir. NRF5_SDK13/TARGET_MCU_NRF52840 -> NRF5/TARGET_MCU_NRF52840

merged changes introduce to BLE port for compatibility with newest SD API
changes FEATURE_BLE(...)/NRF5_SDK13/*.(c,h,cpp) -> FEATURE_BLE(...)/NRF5/*.(c,h,cpp)

merged changes introduce to device hal driver port for compatibility with nRF5 SDK13
NRF5_SDK13/*.(c,h) -> NRF5/*.(c,h)

Added backward compatibility code to API implementation of gpio, pwm, serial, port, spi
Added backward compatibility code to BLE implementation of GAP.

Modified targets description in order to use moved files.

## Purpose of changes
This PR purpose is to reduce Nordic maintenance effort. It introduce coherence between NRF51, NRF52, NRF52840 ports.

## Status
**READY**

title: Config: config header file should contain new line
body:
Tested with ARM

Before this patch
```
Compile [  5.3%]: analogout_api.c
[Warning] mbed_config.h@30,0:  #1-D: last line of file ends without a newline
Compile [ 10.5%]: analogin_api.c
[Warning] mbed_config.h@30,0:  #1-D: last line of file ends without a newline
Compile [ 15.8%]: startup_LPC17xx.S
[Warning] mbed_config.h@30,0:  #1-D: last line of file ends without a newline
Compile [ 21.1%]: can_api.c
[Warning] mbed_config.h@30,0:  #1-D: last line of file ends without a newline
```

After this patch:
```
Compile [  2.2%]: AnalogIn.cpp
Compile [  4.4%]: BusIn.cpp
Compile [  6.7%]: BusOut.cpp
Compile [  8.9%]: BusInOut.cpp
Compile [ 11.1%]: FlashIAP.cpp
Compile [ 13.3%]: Ethernet.cpp
Compile [ 15.6%]: I2C.cpp
Compile [ 17.8%]: CAN.cpp
Compile [ 20.0%]: I2CSlave.cpp
Compile [ 22.2%]: InterruptIn.cpp
Compile [ 24.4%]: SPI.cpp
```

We shall be careful with warnings (not adding more to the codebase that we already have :-) )

@theotherjimmy

title: RTX2: Fix nrf52 crash
body: Various tests, such as tests-mbedmicro-rtos-mbed-basic, fail on the nrf52. This is because the background thread is overflowing on this target - the stack size is 200 bytes while the stack usage is 224 bytes or more. This patch increases the background stack size to 256 bytes to fix this overflow.

title: STM32 Fixed warning related to __packed redefinition
body:
## Description

This PR solves #3932

Before this patch, many warnings like below were generated
during compilation with ArmCC
[Warning] lwip_ethernet.h@57,0:  3135-D: attribute does not apply to any entity

This happens here as ``--gnu`` option of ArmCC is being used, which
enables the GNU compiler extensions that the ARM compiler supports.

This is solved by adding a extra check on __CCARM .

## Status
**READY**

## Tests results
All STM32 based boards compile OK
The patch was also tested with F429ZI Ethernet tests

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17590297/25488019/2c1e734a-2b66-11e7-8b64-6f0305b504d6.png)

**READY**

## Related PRs

* This PR should unblock https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/pull/4185

title: Mbed os workshop 17q2 nordic flash api
body:
## Description
Adding support for flashiap for nRF52840 devices

## Status
**READY**

## Steps to test or reproduce
Tests passed:
mbed test -n "tests-mbed_hal-flash" -t GCC_ARM -m NRF52840_dk
and
mbed test -n "tests-mbed_drivers-flashiap" -t GCC_ARM -m NRF52840_dk

title: CMSIS5: Fix tests failing for small targets
USBHOST hub support for TARGET_STM
body:
## Description
This list of commit brings:
- full speed device support connected on hub for target stm.
- small speed devices connected to hub are not supported

## Status
READY

title: Usb host msd block device
body:
## Description
Since BlockDevice has been introduced USBHostMSD is no more supported.
With this patch USBhostMSD inherits from BlockDevice , and can be used with  FATFileSystem class.
## Migration
As USBHostMSD does not inherit from FATFilesystem any more, the code using the class has to be modified.  
## Status
READY

title: Feature qspi
body:
## Description
Initial QSPI support for mbed. This pull request come with hal and driver prepositions and QSPI hal implementation for nRF52840. I will add simple application which show how to use it (similar to SPI or other serial drivers). There is also layer called memspec. C++ driver uses memspec to configure memory in proper state (SPI or QUAD, 24bit od 32bit addressing mode etc).  This layer was separated from QSPI to allow creating solution based on reading sfdp (serial flash discoverable parameters).
Doxygen was added to every function. 
There are a lot of changes (github counts more than 4k). Lot of them are related to removing spaces from end of the lines in sdk_config.h file. QSPI related changes count less than 2k lines of code.

## Status
**READY**

## Migrations
NO

## Steps to test or reproduce
Simple application will be add as a external example
